description.compact: MySQL connector class.

docblock.description: Supported indexes for :

description.compact: Connection to the DBMS.
True if we are connected to a database.
The name of the database.
Sets the character set for the MySQL database connection.

docblock.description:
The character set connection should be set to 'utf8' for SilverStripe version 2.4.0 and later.
However, sites created before version 2.4.0 should leave this unset or data that isn't 7-bit safe will be corrupted. As such, the installer comes with this set in mysite/_config.php by default in versions 2.4.0 and later.

description.compact: Connect to a MySQL database.

param.description: An map of parameters, which should include:

docblock.param: - server: The server, eg, localhost - username: The username to log on with - password: The password to log on with - database: The database to connect to - timezone: (optional) The timezone offset. For example: +12:00, "Pacific/Auckland", or "SYSTEM"

description.compact: Return a boolean type-formatted string

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

comment.value: For reference, this is what typically gets passed to this function:
$parts=Array('datatype'=>'tinyint', 'precision'=>1, 'sign'=>'unsigned', 'null'=>'not null',
DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "tinyint(1) unsigned not null default

description.compact: Return a date type-formatted string For MySQL, we simply return the word 'date', no other parameters are necessary

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

comment.value: For reference, this is what typically gets passed to this function:
DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "date");

description.compact: Return a decimal type-formatted string

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

comment.value: For reference, this is what typically gets passed to this function:
$parts=Array('datatype'=>'decimal', 'precision'=>"$this->wholeSize,$this->decimalSize");
DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "decimal($this->wholeSize,$this->decimalSize)");
Avoid empty strings being put in the db

description.compact: Return a enum type-formatted string

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

comment.value: For reference, this is what typically gets passed to this function:
$parts=Array('datatype'=>'enum', 'enums'=>$this->enum, 'character set'=>'utf8', 'collate'=>
'utf8_general_ci', 'default'=>$this->default);
DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "enum('" . implode("','", $this->enum) . "') character set
utf8 collate utf8_general_ci default '{$this->default}'");

description.compact: Return a set type-formatted string

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

comment.value: For reference, this is what typically gets passed to this function:
$parts=Array('datatype'=>'enum', 'enums'=>$this->enum, 'character set'=>'utf8', 'collate'=>
'utf8_general_ci', 'default'=>$this->default);
DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "enum('" . implode("','", $this->enum) . "') character set
utf8 collate utf8_general_ci default '{$this->default}'");

description.compact: Return a int type-formatted string

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

comment.value: For reference, this is what typically gets passed to this function:
$parts=Array('datatype'=>'int', 'precision'=>11, 'null'=>'not null', 'default'=>(int)$this->default);
DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "int(11) not null default '{$this->defaultVal}'");

param.description: Contains a tokenised list of info about this data type

description.compact: Return a text type-formatted string

DB::requireField($this->tableName, $this->name, "mediumtext character set utf8 collate utf8_general_ci");

description.compact: function to return an SQL datetime expression that can be used with MySQL used for querying a datetime in a certain format

param.description: to be formated, can be either 'now', literal datetime like '1973-10-14 10:30:00' or
to be used, supported specifiers:

docblock.param: %Y = Year (four digits) %m = Month (01..12) %d = Day (01..31) %H = Hour (00..23) %i = Minutes (00..59) %s = Seconds (00..59) %U = unix timestamp, can only be used on it's own

return.description: SQL datetime expression to query for a formatted datetime

description.compact: function to return an SQL datetime expression that can be used with MySQL used for querying a datetime addition

param.description: can be either 'now', literal datetime like '1973-10-14 10:30:00' or field name,
to be added, use the format [sign][integer] [qualifier],

docblock.param: e.g. -1 Day, +15 minutes, +1 YEAR supported qualifiers: - years - months - days - hours - minutes - seconds This includes the singular forms as well

return.description: SQL datetime expression to query for a datetime (YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss) which is the result of

description.compact: function to return an SQL datetime expression that can be used with MySQL used for querying a datetime substraction

param.description: can be either 'now', literal datetime like '1973-10-14 10:30:00' or field name,
to be substracted of $date1, can be either 'now', literal datetime like

return.description: SQL datetime expression to query for the interval between $date1 and $date2 in seconds which

docblock.return: is the result of the substraction

Execute a complex manipulation on the database.

docblock.description: A manipulation is an array of insert / or update sequences. The keys of the array are table names, and the values are map containing 'command' and 'fields'. Command should be 'insert' or 'update', and fields should be a map of field names to field values, including quotes. The field value can also be a SQL function or similar.

description.compact: Error handler for database errors.

docblock.description: All database errors will call this function to report the error. It isn't a static function; it will be called on the object itself and as such can be overridden in a subclass.

description.compact: Can the database override timezone as a connection setting, or does it use the system timezone exclusively?
Determines if the used database supports application-level locks, which is different from table- or row-level locking.

docblock.description: See for details.

description.compact: Returns if the lock is available.

docblock.description: See to check if locking is generally supported.

description.compact: Sets an application-level lock so that no two processes can run at the same time, also called a "cooperative advisory lock".

docblock.description: Return FALSE if acquiring the lock fails; otherwise return TRUE, if lock was acquired successfully. Lock is automatically released if connection to the database is broken (either normally or abnormally), making it less prone to deadlocks than session- or file-based locks. Should be accompanied by a call after the logic requiring the lock has completed. Can be called multiple times, in which case locks "stack" (PostgreSQL, SQL Server), or auto-releases the previous lock (MySQL). Note that this might trigger the database to wait for the lock to be released, delaying further execution.

param.description: Timeout in seconds

description.compact: Remove an application-level lock file to allow another process to run (if the execution aborts (e.g. due to an error) all locks are automatically released).
